Pros:
Interviewing with Bolt consisted of 4-5 conversations with leaders and stakeholders I'd be working alongside on a daily basis/supporting. Interviewers were engaging and it was a very positive experience overall. 

Once hired, onboarding took about 1-2 weeks and was very organized. Had more than enough support in terms of both materials and colleagues to get up to speed on Bolt's product, culture, etc. 
Pay and benefits are strong - company is remote-first, Pay is competitive (at/above industry average), and benefits are in alignment with other tech companies in the space. 

Despite previous re-structures and changes in the organization the last few years, leaders are/have been transparent about the changes, the reasons behind them, and the vision/plan for Bolt moving forward. 

Product is interesting and a disrupter in the e-commerce space. You'll have the opportunity to work on/support the development of a product that supports well known brands everyone knows which is cool. 

There have been changes in leadership recently, and as a new hire, it seems from both a company vision/GTM strategy, as well as an employee morale standpoint, they are for the better. Individual contributors and leaders alike are aligned on the vision for the company and the product moving forward and are making a concerted effort to create a culture of more communication, transparency, and openness within all aspects of the organization. 

Definitely a startup culture where they prioritize hiring individuals who are able to/enjoy working autonomously, are strong culture builders, optimistic, and take ownership and accountability on the work they contribute. While there are more than enough systems/processes put in place, you also will have the opportunity to create processes from scratch or iterate on them. This may not be for everyone, but if you enjoy working in a high growth/scrappy startup environment, you will likely enjoy the type of work you get to do here.
Cons: Because of the multiple changes that have been made in the last 6-12 months, there may be some people that may not be aligned with the new vision/strategy of the company or new leadership moving forward. That being said, leadership has made a concerted effort to address this misalignment head on and have candid conversations about the future rather than not addressing people's apprehensions. From everything I've seen, department leaders and the executive team have taken a very humanistic approach to addressing people's concerns, and you can/will be heard and seen as a valued member of the Bolt organization.

Pros: There is a lot of opportunity to roll up your sleeves and take on ownership that influence the strategic direction of the business. Bolt is going through a transformational shift and has great people in place across the board to help drive that. This is a great time to join if you like building, owning your domain, and innovating.
Cons: Bolt moves fast, there is no question about it. Often times, moving fast means things break. It's expected in a startup, but sometimes there are pieces to pick up and fix/solve when the company moves so quickly.

Pros:
- It's my first week here but already feel incredibly welcomed. I've been impressed and more quickly acclimated by a super robust onboarding and all the Culture Meetings too (Firedsides, Affinity Group Events, etc.).
- Am learning about the benefits of Bolt's value of writing over talking. I've been at other startups and this is by far the most organized, the most accountable, the quickest and the most transparent.
- I, even from the interview process, feel like I can be myself here. Bolt encourages uniqueness and celebrating our team (all parts of us), and I'm happy that there's less posturing (that people don't seem fake/political/game-playing at work) and more genuine openness and realness.
- Bolt truly believes in the value of doing right by, and supporting, all the teammates. So far it seems like the company has prioritized various efforts, services and perks to help employees have a better work experience (I'm obviously biased, but I think that's hugely important).
Cons: - Bolt is still a startup, and feels like one (for better but also for worse in some cases). I feel confident that the company will keep fine-tuning processes and policies, but everyone who joins will have to bring their proactiveness, creativity and a little patience to the table.

Pros:
The people! Of all the places I've worked and interviewed at, Bolt rises to the top. The people are driven and intelligent, and are surprisingly very down to earth and eager to get to know new folks. And that's not just within engineering-- everyone across the company is phenomenal and you'll get to know everyone.

There is also a ton of work to be done. Our CEO (Ryan) has a really ambitious vision for Bolt's product, and if you're the type of person that thrives when given a lot of responsibility, Bolt is a great place to be.

The key differentiator for Bolt is the size of the problem we're trying to solve. If realized, the Bolt vision would change the landscape for online retail in a huge way. Not a single one of the other startups I interviewed at felt like a gamechanger in the same way that Bolt could be.

Also the snacks are :fire:
Cons:
There is definitely a level of uncertainty that you need to be comfortable with. Know that if you're joining a startup, there is risk involved that you wouldn't be taking on if you joined a big company.

From a technical standpoint there isn't as much developer tooling as what you'd find at a big company. That being said, we have some absolutely amazing people working hard to make developer's lives easier and every week there's another improvement. There are also a lot of things about the development process at Bolt that are actually better than what you'd find at a big company, but know that there will be some differences.

Pros:
- The product is unbeatable. Not only is it a need-to-have, but there's also a mission driven component to stopping fraud and empowering merchants. It's a win-win for everyone.
- Our culture is genuine, and even though we have some of the smartest people in FinTech working here, there's no egos. People are just excited to drive the needle, which every person has the ability to do!
- Playbooks and processes are either already built out or are in the process of being built out.  This makes scaling a startup way more efficient, and is a big reason we've been able to grow as fast as we have.

Cons:
Like many high-growth startups, the environment is fast-paced, change is regular, everybody has a lot on their plate, and some parts of the organization are more mature in their processes and decision-making than others.  

To that end, being successful at Bolt requires you to:

- Be highly thoughtful about what is a priority and what can be accomplished over a specific time frame, and be comfortable saying "no" to projects or goals that are unrealistic or not yet a priority.
-  Take time to build foundations, organizing information & data so that team members can make decisions quickly and then disseminate information about those decisions to key stakeholders with high efficiency.

Currently, not every team or every individual makes the time to do the above on a regular basis, which can result in friction between teams and individuals. However, over the course of my time at the company, people have improved in these regards significantly and I have little doubt that we will only get better as time goes on.

Pros:
-Good Benefits: Bolt has the stereotypical Silicon valley benefits package, catered lunches, snacks, company events, etc. The two that I think are really nice are the extremely good healthcare options, the transportation compensation, and the other miscellaneous insurance benefits, like life insurance. There's also a flexible PTO system that people are actually encouraged to use.

-Great Future Outlook: As of the time of writing this review, COVID-19 and the imminent financial recession are very worrying. Bolt's product, future outlook, and current financial situation are all great counters to this. It's great being able to work from home during this time and not be worried about Bolt going out of business. In general I also feel really optimistic about our product's financial viability. 

-Company Culture: While this definitely varies by team, I really enjoy the company atmosphere.  It's definitely relaxed, but people are held to the standards they need to be meeting.

-Great Risk Team: I'm a risk analyst, so this matters most for the purposes of my review. Since I've started, our team has exceeded expectations and goals. It's nice being part of a group that is successful.
Cons:
-Some Growing Pains: There's definitely been a transitional shift between when I started working here and now. Early on the company was definitely an early stage startup, where as now leadership has shifted to trying to actually be viable and make money and not just rapid expansion. There were some issues along the way, one of which is that our sales and talent teams were restructured. Obviously layoffs are unpleasant, but they seemed necessary for long term success.

-Engineering Focus: Bolt's culture does feel a little to heavily centered around programmers/engineers. It can sometimes feel like they are running the show in terms of resource allocation. From a risk team perspective this means we get a lot less development of our tools and features compared to other areas of the company.

Pros:

The product is a unique and has no immediate competition. This makes it exciting to sell and engaging  to watch the progress of our offerings. The sky is the limit with this platform. 

We move quickly and have had to make tough decisions related to specific organizational restructuring. These are things that are never easy but are critical in the calculated growth of the company. These difficult decisions were made thoughtfully and have set up the company for continued success.

Bolt is the best of both worlds -- we have all of the resources we could ever need and none of the red-tape that slows things down. We are encouraged to pursue 10x improvements, to take risks and try new things. When they don't go as planned, we reflect on the learnings, get back up as a team and try again. 

I often find myself working alongside some of the most intelligent and driven individuals, I've ever met. I'm continuously amazed at all of the things we are able to accomplish in accelerated timelines. From new feature launches and integrations, to landing page builds, webinars and new candidate recruiting everything moves at light speed. 

We’ve all heard the expression that “when you do something you love, you’ll never work a day in your life” — I never thought that this could actually happen, but I can honestly say it’s true. I often find myself coming home late at night with more energy and enthusiasm than I’ve ever felt before. The people at Bolt have become my friends and my mentors.
